review_title: Great Work Enviornment, but the Company Says a Lot it Doesn't Mean
pros: -Excellent management across most units -Incredible team-based learning and work environment -401k, and 3% company match -Regular bonuses for picking up on some shifts -Excellent union at Akron General location
cons: The company states they are dedicated to diversity and the comfort of all caregivers. I can comfortably say this is not true. Regular homophobia and transphobia towards coworkers goes unpunished. Nursing supervisors have lied to LGBT staff about who is head of diversity and inclusion. I have transgender coworkers who are forced to wear their deadname on their nametag. Multiple cisgender coworkers are not required to do this. Additionally, some units promote an environment where work ethic comes second to comfort. This is really a product of groupthink, so if you're a hard worker people will notice and step up their game as well, but it can very frustrating. Lastly, the pay is frustratingly pitiful for what the work is. Techs work very hard, and many of us struggle to put food on the table. If you're a fresh college graduate, this job will not let you move out of your parents' place. It will, however, give you healthcare experience. Just don't think the company values you enough to pay you what you're worth.

review_title: Great breaks. Lack of respect. Collections type work.

Higher up’s fail to notice how much patience, knowledge, and skill it takes to be employed there.
cons: No raises, people constantly talking about you, cold office always, loud team members that make the patient you’re speaking with angry at you when it wasn’t you being loud or laughing. I would only recommend this job to people that are looking to be employed in this field, less than a year. If you’re seeking long term, look elsewhere!

review_title: Toxic/cover-up culture, disorganised and unsupportive - Cleveland Clinic London PHARMACY

cons: Lack of communication on all levels in the pharmacy department and amongst management. Lack of pharmacist training and support despite raising risk and safety concerns for patients. pros: Co workers including MDs , EVS, etc
cons: Management makes it really difficult for employees to do best for patients. They leave us so short handed and the documentation for something as simple as getting consent can take 45 mins, simple lab work as well. They set us up for failure and it’s no wonder the patients are fed up. I can’t apologize to them enough and it is out of my control. Administration needs to either be a patient themselves or shadow the staff to believe these time consuming detours the staff must go through just to get a simple task completed. It’s insanity. I work alongside skilled professionals and we are great providers to our patients however the documentation they expect from us and the volume of patients they expect us to care for makes it nearly impossible to do “they best we can” We are losing smart and experienced caregivers daily due to the workload and what administration expects we can handle. They don’t expect us to take breaks either, I can’t give my assignment to another caregiver for even 10 minutes because they have an equally hard assignment. We also get reprimanded if we don’t take a break. You just can’t win.

review_title: Good experience in research, but a lack of diversity and elitist culture.
pros: It’s a great place to learn your skills, test out your degree, and build a resume.
cons:
People in the research department are very judgmental. I got constructive feedback as an intern, which of course was helpful. However, when I asked for help on how to get rehired and to look over my resume, they said that people at my university aren’t known for being the best applicant and that they only hire people from Case or U of M. It made me very confused for the longest time because I couldn’t afford to go to either of those universities. 

In the research facilities, they are non-diverse. They say that they have a lot of people from a lot of places working there, but it is mostly white or Asian. I didn’t see many any other people from different economic backgrounds besides privileged in positions of power either (running the research labs). This affects the ability to come up with different scientific research ideas and problem solving techniques! 

Parking as an intern  stinks at the main campus. Parking as a full time employee at the main campus is expensive (you have to pay). As an intern, you get no benefits.

cons: Underpaid. The expectations do not match the compensation. Management can be unsupportive and I have also been evaluated by my manager incorrectly. Management only observed me working for approximately 10 minutes in a 9 month period of time. It seems very inappropriate for them to craft my review and judge my work performance based on this. Some critiques by management are not backed up by examples or facts. Corporate Cleveland Clinic does not offer the same security safeguards as well as perks and benefits to smaller locations.

review_title: A trap for people looking for experience
job_title: Research Technician II in Cleveland, OH
pros: You do get great healthcare benefits.
cons: There is no support for the staff. This was definitely a trap for people who are looking for experience. I worked in the research portion of the clinic (LRI) straight out of undergrad and it was definitely a trap. The clinic hides behind it's name. You are severely underpaid (20% below industry value) and overworked. Additionally, 9/10 of the PI's do not truly help you further your goals. Also, the LRI HR does not support YOU the staff. It will allow for incompetent people to continue to work there while not actually stopping perpetrators of a toxic workplace, harassment, and overall poor work. The clinic would rather be "politically correct" than fire someone or support their female employees. Walking away from my experience of the clinic I didn't realize how bad it was until I ended up in a workplace in which my talents and life were valued.

review_title: Stressful work environment with poor productivity
pros: Health insurance is very good and treatment at the clinic is very good
cons:
The work environment is very high pressure, results are expected quickly and mistakes are not tolerated. This causes scientific problems when results are not as expected that makes work unrpoductive. I regularly work more than 60 hours a week and sometimes up to 80 hours when it is time for grant renewal. Promotion upwards does occur but there is a glass ceiling and it very difficult to become a manager if you are not American or Canadian due to funding rules. 

Vacations are frowned upon and not always approved. One person has to work thru each holiday period to keep work flowing while others are away. 

The visa system means that it is difficult to leave the USA/Canada when working here. I was not able to attend my father's funeral as I was not allowed to take time off to renew my visa.

cons: Cleveland Clinic need to have a better plan regarding opportunities for leadership positions. Cleveland Clinic should count years of experience for college educations if you don't have one. review_title: Don't waste your time - disorganized management and hidden costs
job_title: Research Data Scientist in Chicago, IL
pros: You'll enjoy this job if you like being underpaid, and then being asked to take on hidden expenses that were never disclosed during the hiring process
cons:
- Condescending and disorganized management 

- Expected me to cover all equipment and maintenance costs for remote work but didn't say this upfront (travel costs, job duties outside of scope, laptop/monitors/keyboard, high speed internet, etc.). 

- When I said I couldn't use my own PC for the job, they said I could use a retired laptop they'd mail with all licenses stripped, and expected me to cover a $150 licensure cost. When it didn't arrive after two weeks, they stopped paying me even though it was their fault for choosing a poor shipping method, and had initially told me that I would be paid to do other tasks while waiting for the equipment. No apology or accountability for their role in this

- Only way to decrease health insurance premiums is to meet certain arbitrary health goals

- When you ask around, most responses show that they have a track record of habitually overworking and underpaying their staff

pros:

In regards to a lot of the negative reviews- they just changed the 2 year minimum rule a couple days ago. You can now apply for a new position within the Clinic after 1 year.

…. Ironically, some of the cons also addressed high turnover rate, which I fear this might not help with. A lot of people do move onto other positions (e.g. private companies that pay better). On the plus side, this is a great position to help you get there; on the con side, we do have pretty crazy workloads covering for high turnovers.

Benefits are great (of course, working for CCF)- two options depending on whether you want to be sticking mostly within the Clinic or paying a little more for more options…. But the Clinic had so many experienced specialists, the only reason I could see paying extra is if you wanted to stick with a previous out-of-network provider.

Pay is fair compared to RCs at other hospitals and promotions/raises are good. Obviously not as much as private companies, hence most of the turnover.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: My coworkers are amazing. We support each other and I have made many friends. As a clinical researcher, my hours are flexible and I have the ability to work from home two days a week.
cons: The Cleveland Clinic pays the least of the hospital systems. All the articles on their intranet are full of comments from people begging for wage increases as most people I know there have to work second or third jobs and they are still losing money each pay cycle. Management is out of touch and you can consistently hear them on calls insisting on keeping raises and salaries "as conservative as possible". Most people in my department have gone to management explaining how they work multiple jobs and still cannot afford groceries, but they will flat out ignore this and focus on different things that you are saying and completely sweep your concerns under the rug. People are leaving at a high rate, and staffing is extremely short- you will be very over-worked. Meanwhile, the top earners in the company are making more than the surrounding hospitals, as the "little people" earn less than the competitors. CCF continues to grow and expand and invest money in new locations despite not having the resources or money to staff their current hospitals due to their worker shortage. And in institutional meetings, management will say things about how they need to focus on hiring physicians and that the support staff who "aren't doing anything" can pick up the slack and stop being lazy and take on more responsibilities. Personally, as support staff, most days I do not even have time to take a lunch, but my manager will reprimand me for this, so I allow them to commit wage theft every day I clock out and lie and say I received a lunch. I also cannot fit my normal work obligations into only 40 hrs a week, so this is also necessary for that purpose. My manager boasted to me in interviews that she looks for ways to promote so I could grow and develop in this company, yet since I've been there, the only people who have been promoted were people who were threatening to leave the job due to issues like pay, and were then promoted to try to keep them. I was also lied to in interviews and told I would be doing things in my actual interest area, only to find out that this would never happen. I am working lead on 4 studies, spending a lot of time helping out 2 other studies, and trying to get more up and running as a coordinator 1 level with only 1 year on the job. I am doing the work of a coordinator 2, and applied for the position of a coordinator 2, but they put me at a 1 level upon hire and kept my duties and obligations the same just as a way to save money and keep me underpaid. I have been at the clinic 5 total years and have switched departments multiple times thinking the next department would be better, but these are company wide issues. When jumping 4 pay grades from a promotion, my salary only went up $2/hour. Overall, my projection for the clinic is extremely negative. Maybe one day they will realize their employees are leaving at a mass rate due to under appreciation, under staffing, over working, and under paying, but until then, I would not recommend coming onboard.

pros: One of the best places to work

pros: Good healthcare benefit..... thats literally the only reason worth working here.
cons: I spent 1 year working there and during that time I saw about 15 coworkers get hired within weeks/months after will quit/be fired. And those are just the people in my row. If you are late by only 1 minute it counts as a whole day of being tardy and if you get a few of these, they can easily fire you for it. The micromanaging in this department is INSANE. All of the managers were biased, rude, and played "favorites" with certain employees. There was even a time where they were trying to get me in trouble for things that weren't even my fault and I truly believe it was because they wanted to push my to my breaking point until I quit. They probably just didn't want to pay for unemployment so this was their next best strategy. The rules for the calls during the workday were totally unrealistic. We constantly felt "damned if we do, damned if we don't" with many of the tasks during the day. If you worked here, you know exactly what im talking about. The pay is pathetic for the amount of work they have you do during the day. I worked full time and could barely afford even half of my bills. Some people only worked here for the good health insurance. Oh, and if you think you are going to "stick to it until you move up into a better position", youre very mistaken. There is no moving up from the appointment center. They have a rule that you have to work for a minimum of 2 years before you can apply to other departments in the hospital (unless you are fortunate enough to get an exception from your manager). I worked there while completing my Master's degree with the hopes of finding a better position after I graduated. I quickly learned that it was never going to happen unless your best friends with the boss. I ABSOLUTELY DO NOT recommend working at Cleveland Clinic as it is a waste of your time, energy, and mental health.

review_title: Great place to build upon professional knowledge and clinical practice; toxic work culture/environment
pros: This is a good place to work if you want to enhance your professional knowledge in nursing and medicine. I think this company looks best on your resume if you are a physician or resident; I can't say whether it means a ton to a nursing recruiter or manager on a resume (unless your specialty holds a #1 ranking for best care: cardiology, GI surgery, urology). This company also has a multitude of different resources that you can access to help improve your overall practice and expertise, OR if you want to work in a highly specialized area of nursing and medicine. I learned a lot from this company in a very short amount of time.
cons: This company has all the negative aspects related to working in corporate healthcare, specifically in the teaching hospital setting - long shifts, high turnover, toxic coworkers/managers, high stress, incredibly fast paced, profit driven outcomes, hierarchical culture, politics, physically and emotionally unsafe working conditions, noncompetitive wages, workplace violence via patients & colleagues, I could go on...I'm speaking specifically from my experience as a bedside RN. I worked at main campus, a.k.a 'The Mothership' lol. It's ranked as one of the best hospitals in the world for a reason, but, proceed with utmost caution. Nurses, doctors, and other caregivers are under constant pressure to DO MORE. Find a healthy support system, acquire a side hustle or fun hobby if you have the energy/time after working your 12 hr+ shifts, and maybe talk to your PCP about starting an antidepressant prior to you embarking on employment here.

review_title: Unfair compensation for workload and experience
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Cleveland, OH
pros: Seems like a really great place at first. Works for some types of people.
cons: When I first joined the culture was very nice. They encouraged everyone to go home on time. After about a year the expectation started becoming more and more demanding. The hours started becoming longer and the expectation started becoming that if you didn’t stay overtime to finish the work then you would be punished for not finishing your work. However this was a job where there was no expectation or compensation for working this many hours overtime. Overtime I started finding out that they did not compensate fairly not only for myself for the overtime hours but that they also don’t adjust pay in a timely manner for experience. The new people they hire in at market rate can be hire than people who have worked with for them for years. This was for doctors as well as entry level jobs. I think they need to understand where they stand in terms of compensation before they demand this type of workload. On a non monetary standpoint there is no set progression. You can only advance if a position opens up. So no matter how well you do at the end of the year there is no additional pay and no promotion guaranteed indefinitely.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Cleveland, OH
pros:
There are a lot of educational opportunities, and you'll get good experience with time management. 

The healthcare benefits are really incredible (as long as you see ONLY Cleveland Clinic providers) and prescription costs are low. 

The point system for call-outs is fair (1 point for calling off before 4, 5 points allotted in a rolling year, with 1 permitted instance where you can call off three shifts in a row and it only counts as one point -- but you have to know you're doing it in advance, and tell them as you call in on the first shift).

The name and prestige looks good on a resume.
cons:
Beware: The Clinic tells you that it's mandatory to work two years on a unit before you transfer to any other floor within the entire CCF hospital system. If you don't, you're blacklisted. Really consider all your options before you take a job here because once you do, you're stuck. 

Pay: Insultingly low. No merit increase this past year, although we did get a $500 (pre-tax) bonus recently. 

Charge nurse: On many floors, the charge nurse is forced to take on all the charge duties -- AND a full patient assignment -- for NO extra pay.

Floating: All RNs at main campus are required to float to any unit in the hospital, regardless of specialty or staffing needs on YOUR unit. This goes for highly experienced RNs as well as nurses fresh off orientation. Expect to float to neurology step-down, oncology, med-surg, ortho, women's health, leukemia, bone marrow transplant, GI, pulmonary, Covid units, bariatric, and whatever other unit can't keep staff. Last year they were requiring us to float to different regional hospitals entirely. 

Understaffing: Getting worse and worse due to massive staff turnover and a constant churn-and-burn of new grads. Always short-staffed, and if they aren't already short-staffed at the start of the shift, they will float nurses to other units that "need them more." Cuts in staff mean nurses are assigned the responsibility to draw all patients' labs (Phlebotomy rarely shows up anymore), do all EKGs, etc. They don't even notify us they're short anymore, they just...don't show up.

Burnout: Everyone is burned out. Nurses, aides, management, everyone. Management does not address the widespread dissatisfaction or acknowledge how difficult, unsafe and frustrating the floating has been.

review_title: Let their employees die rather than provide proper PPE
pros: The healthcare plan isn't the worst
cons: The Cleveland Clinic is patients first, employees last. Everyone who works here knows it. During the pandemic, upper management refused to allow caregivers to wear N95s, even when access to proper PPE was widely available. They only just NOW (July of 2021) are letting all caregivers who work WITH COVID+ PATIENTS wear N95s, and that's only because OSHA is mandating it. They watched silently as the entire staff of many units became ill with the virus, some never to return. They literally watched caregivers die because of refusing to let them have the same PPE their epidemiologists preached was needed when in contact with COVID positive patients. All while insisting everyone was getting sick through contact outside of the hospital- which we all know is a blatant lie. I don't understand how somehow this hospital is ranked consistently in the top 3 nationwide. They bill home health as inpatient to cut loopholes to earn more money and have the employees work holidays. They pay the lowest in the area. The turnover in every department is incredibly high- I only know a small handful of people who stay here beyond 2 or 3 years. Management is fake and talks about people behind their backs; they clearly do not care about the wellbeing of their employees. We were offered NO hazard pay, which many other hospitals were able to do. All we got was a "generous gift" of $500 for working through the pandemic that was taxed as a gift instead of a bonus so we only received about half of that about (of course they want to be able to use that for their tax returns). I've had management talk about my PHI openly in teams meetings with the entire department in front of me. The level of disrespect is unreal. But if you speak out about any of it, you're the problem.

review_title: The Marketing team is second to none. The entire team is driven, smart, creative, and a fantastic group to work with.
pros: You will learn a lot. They are a number one hospital for a reason. They are always pushing to reach its audiences in the newest and most innovative ways possible. While goals are of course to drive business, this is a hospital that also cares deeply about its patients, and does well to understand them. And they work hard to make sure that message comes through in all of its messaging. And the physicians that work here are incredible. Some of the smartest, most ambitious individuals I have ever had the pleasure of working with.
cons: Work-life balance is poor. The Marketing department goes above and beyond. Not your normal 8-5. To succeed, you need to be able to work long hours, sometimes weekends, and are expected to be in the office or at main campus. There’s really no working from home or flexibility. It can be hard when you’re starting a family and may need a more flexible position. Also, the Clinic notoriously underpays, at least in the marketing department. However, the benefits really make up for it. You’ll never find a better healthcare plan, and I think it’s one of the last places to still offer a pension plan in addition to a matched 401k.
